One person who is wearing a green hat is sitting next to one person who is wearing the red hat, while another person who is wearing blue hat is sitting in between two people who are wearing white hats.  The person standing next to the person wearing the blue hat is wearing a green or a red hat.  One person that is wearing a red hat is sitting next to a person who is wearing green hat.<n><n>### Response answer: There are a total of 4 white hats. Choices:  B: blue C: white D: purple E: brown<n><n>## Output<n>> Choose'C' from 'A' to 'E'<n><n>### Test<n>> 1. 6+1=7<n>2. 3.f+7=4<n>3. 2f+5=17<n>4. 20<32<n>5. 9>11<n><n>### Check<n>```html<n><pre><n>	4*1.2=4.8<n>	8+2=10<n>	-15=-15<n>	-1>1/2<n>	4>1/4<n>	60/8=7.5<n>	15+2=17<n>	4>7<n>	2<=2<n>	4>3<n>	3<=4<n>	5>=3<n>	7>=3<n>	4>=4<n>	19 > 15<n>	1/3 < 1/3<n>	0 == 5<n>	6 > 5<n>	5 <= 5<n>	10 > 15<n></pre><n>```<n><n>### Output:<n>```html<n>	6*8=48 <br><n>	11/14=0.78 <br><n>```<n>

Open a file called 'output.txt'<n>2. Get a random number 'random_no' from 0 to 255<n>3. Write the character "A" to the file.<n>4. Read in what the file has so far.<n>5. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:What  might john order at an indian resturant on top of the space needle? Choices:  A: large city B: seattle C: curry D: clothing E: reservation<n><n>### Response:		<n>If his purchases had cost $56 for example, then the sales tax applied would be 56X0.05 = $2.8, so the total cost of his items would be $56+2.8= $58.8.<n><n>### Input 2:What might johns order at an indian restaurant on top of the space neal? Choice: A: Large city B: SeaTac C: Currey D: clothing E; Reservation<n><n>###  Response<n>Since John went to the gym on monday, we assumed he went for three hours of weight lifting and one hour for warm up and warm up plus one hour of cardio, so on his monday visit he spent 4 hours. He then went to the gym every day during the week, so on his friday visit, (the last of the week which ends on sunday), he will have spent 28 hours, so the answer to this question is 28.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:There aren't many anemone in what glove-shaped state? Choices:  A: michigan B: lake C: tide pool D: nursery E: atlantic ocean<n><n>### Response:		Lake<n><n>### Why?<n>The sentence that I've given you says that there aren't many anamone in "what glove-shaped" state. So you need to figure out which word the sentence starts off with and is that a state with the word glove. Well if you can think of some states that would have a glove and you can imagine a bunch of other states then you should pick B. For example, Lake Michigan doesn't have any gloves but it looks like one which is a good thing to remember. That's how I got through that question, I'm sure there are other ways but this one seemed to work the most.<n><n>### What if the states are not "glove-shaped"?<n>Then I think you should choose E: Atlantic Ocean, because, "If water would be a glove-shaped then it would be Lake Michigan, so lake michigan isn't glove-shaped, so we would need to go to the next option: Atlantic Ocean" so, my guess is that if it isn't glove shaped then 2 choices will be lake michigan and Atlantic Ocean. I don't know why lake Michigan wasn't lake Michigan but it's most likely because Lake Michigan is a lake that has an o without any r by it. I hope I made this clear.<n><n>### If there isn't "glove-like" in the question, or if the glove has another word besides "glove", then what to do?<n>Well, for the word glove: I got it right cause it is a part of the ocean that has waves. My teacher says to think of the most "out there" or "eccentric" things you can think of and try to get those choices. If we can't think of any then we can ask a friend or the teacher but always follow up with "Which one seems to the most likely to be the correct one?". I was able to get through all my questions by thinking of what the weirdest thing i could think of that is correct, and I also thought if this question is hard then maybe the person that asked it doesn't think my question was hard.<n>Also, if it was a math problem then just draw a picture or a circle on your paper in order to get what word you need. That's how some of my math problems go.

One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:The boy was too nervous to dance, so what was he doing progressively at the ball? Choices:  A: dance like crazy B: standing still C: wallflower D: stand still E: like dancing<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: C<n><n>* Input: The boy was too nervous dancing at the ball which made him behave in a manner of a wallflower.  <n>* Explanation: The word that begins with "dan" in the sentence that you should choose from for the response is "wallflower".  <n>* Answer: Response: C<n><n>## Concepts:<n>* Python Data Structures - List<n>

Choices:  an: disinterested in correcting his faulty actions. b: motivated, so he'll correct his actions c: motivated to fix his mistakes d: doesn't expect punishment<n><n>### Response"An" because what he says here in the statement about the employee's action is that he is aware that there'll be a punishment when he knows, it's not to be disinterested or to correct his faulty actions, he might not correct them because even when there would be a punishment he may not be motivated to correct his actions but once he knows there will be a punishment, he'll not be motivated to improve them because he'll not be disinterested again.

Choices:  A: fire B: solar energy C: sun D: house E: coal or wood<n><n>### Response:		(in the text)<n><n>### Input/Response:<n><n><n><n>### Input<n>Given two numbers N and K, write a program that creates a string<n>in which every number from K (starting from 0) is replaced by its<n>ASCII value (a number from 48-57).<n><n>### Input Example 1:<n>```<n>Input: A = 1, B = 2, C = 0, D = 3, E = 4, F = 99, K = 2<n>Output: AB9CF107<n>```<n><n>### Input Examples 2 (Buggy!)<n>```<n>Input: K = 2, A = -1, B = 10, C = 9<n>Expected Output: AB(incorrect answer)<n>```<n><n>## Instructions<n>Input:<n>Write a program that will print out all the strings which have all even numbers. A string is either empty or has at least one character in it. For example, “1012” is a string because it contains 1,0,1,2, but “a” is not a string because it does not contain at least a single character. The characters “a”, “A”, “-” and “,“ are all considered a single “character”. The order of the characters in the string is not important.<n><n>Answer:<n>Output: 1012<n><n>## InputExamples: 10 101 1012 101 a -!, ( )<n><n>## Instrucions <n><n>```<n>Input: An integer, P, is given.  If P is a number between 1 through 10, then print "P works!"; otherwise print "No P please!".<n>```<n><n># Input<n><n>`int p;`<n><n># Output<n><n>No P please!<n><n># Explanation<n><n>```<n>The input integer is checked to ensure the number is between 1 and 10. If it isn't, it will print "No P please!"<n>```<n>

If you know answer B, F, and G, choose C.  <n>If you donít know what the question is asking, choose D.  <n>If you are confused, answer E.  <n>Choose A. The correct answers are D, E, C.<n><n>### Input<n>I need you to get my luggage from the car to my room, and to put the cushions on the couch.<n><n>### Response<n>I'll give you $1 to get it to the room and $1 to put the cushion on the couch. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Adam bought 3 kilograms of nuts and 2.5 kilograms of dried fruits at a store. One kilogram of nuts costs $12 and one kilogram of dried fruit costs $8. How much did his purchases cost?<n>Answer: 56<n><n>Input: Johns goes to the gym 3 times a week.  He spends 1 hour each day lifting weight. Additionally, he also spends a third of his weightlifting time warming up and doing cardio each day.  How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:Where could you put some olives to prevent them from getting nearby food wet? Choices:  A: eaten B: glassess C: jar D: pizza E: refrigerator<n><n>### Response:		Input:<n><n>**A**: Olives, like any other fruit, get better with the appropriate amount of time and conditions they are ripened in. Olives are generally oval or oblong in shape with a thin skin and a very firm edible stone or pit surrounded by a pulp that is eaten with pimento. The olive is a traditional symbol of peace and wisdom. The color of the olive fruit varies from light green to deep purple depending on its level of ripeness. The flavor profile of the olive is typically bitter, oily and astringent.<n><n>**B**: Olives, on the other hand, are best eaten cold, hence the refrigeration.<n><n>**C**: Olives, by nature, require a lot of moisture. If you let your olives sit out on the counter for more than a few days, you will notice that they dry up pretty quickly. When the olives are stored in oil, the oil replaces some of the moisture which helps them to retain their quality. When stored in an airtight container, olives can last for months without losing their flavor or nutritional value.<n><n>**D**: Pizza is often made with olives as well. You can also use olives to add flavor or color to your dishes if you don’t like the taste of the oil. Olives also contain healthy fats and are high in fiber. You can freeze your olives and they will still be tasty.<n><n>**E**: I suggest you to try adding some olives to your dishes. Olives and pizza go really well together. The flavor of olives is mild enough to be enjoyed with almost any pizza.<n><n><n>[Click Me for the next problem set](ProblemSet_09_Array_Array.md)

How many hours does he spend at the gym a week?<n>Answer: 4<n><n>### Input:James wanted to stop competing.  What might he have been feeling?
